title: Cincinnati–Louisville rivalry
text:
The Cincinnati–Louisville rivalry is a college <a href="sports%20rivalry">sports rivalry</a> between the <a href="University%20of%20Cincinnati">University of Cincinnati</a> <a href="Cincinnati%20Bearcats">Bearcats</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Louisville">University of Louisville</a> <a href="Louisville%20Cardinals">Cardinals</a>. The rivalry between these two schools, located about apart, dates to their first men's <a href="college%20basketball">college basketball</a> game in 1921, and has continued across all sports, with the <a href="college%20football">football</a> series gaining attention as well, having started in 1929. Both universities share common characteristics, both being over 200 year old institutions in urban settings. The schools have also shared conferences historically, with the rivalry stretching over the span of four conferences from the <a href="Missouri%20Valley%20Conference">Missouri Valley Conference</a>, to the <a href="Metro%20Conference">Metro Conference</a> to <a href="Conference%20USA">Conference USA</a>, and more recently in the <a href="Big%20East%20Conference%20%281979%E2%80%932013%29">Big East Conference</a>, which in 2013 was renamed to the <a href="American%20Athletic%20Conference">American Athletic Conference</a>. After the 2013–14 season, Louisville joined the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> and since then the rivalry has been put on hiatus in football and basketball. However, many other sports at the universities, such as baseball, continue to battle periodically.
History.
Both universities have traced parallel paths, from their early foundation in the early nineteenth century as municipal universities to their later growth into <a href="University%20system">state sponsored institutions</a> in the 1960s and 70s. Due to their close proximity, the universities became early athletic opponents as college athletics developed first facing off in 1921 in a men's <a href="college%20basketball">college basketball</a> game. Additionally, this proximity led to both schools being members of the <a href="Missouri%20Valley%20Conference">Missouri Valley Conference</a>, <a href="Metro%20Conference">Metro Conference</a>, <a href="Conference%20USA">Conference USA</a>, and the <a href="Big%20East%20Conference%20%281979%E2%80%932013%29">Big East Conference</a> historically. While the rivalry was represented annually in Football from 1966–1992 and 1996–2013, the true intensity of the rivalry was felt on the basketball court. Legendary coaches <a href="Denny%20Crum">Denny Crum</a>, <a href="Bob%20Huggins">Bob Huggins</a>, and <a href="Rick%20Pitino">Rick Pitino</a> each played their part in famous wins for each program and fanning the flames of the matchup.
In the last year of the rivalry in football and basketball for the foreseeable future, the contests lived up to the pressure. In the battle for <a href="The%20Keg%20of%20Nails">The Keg of Nails</a>, <a href="Teddy%20Bridgewater">Teddy Bridgewater</a> led the No. 19 Cardinals to an overtime comeback at <a href="Nippert%20Stadium">Nippert Stadium</a> much to the ire of the Bearcat faithful. On the hardwood both teams would claim upset, ranked wins at their opponent's home court. <a href="Sean%20Kilpatrick">Sean Kilpatrick</a> lead the Bearcats to a 69–66 victory at the <a href="KFC%20Yum%21%20Center">KFC Yum! Center</a> while <a href="Russ%20Smith%20%28basketball%29">Russ Smith</a> and the Cardinals would beat the Bearcats 58–57 at <a href="Fifth%20Third%20Arena">Fifth Third Arena</a> in their last matchup as conference foes.
On April 30, 2019 <a href="John%20Brannen%20%28basketball%29">John Brannen</a> and <a href="Chris%20Mack%20%28basketball%29">Chris Mack</a> exchanged tweets announcing a renewal of the <a href="Cincinnati%E2%80%93Louisville%20rivalry%23Men%27s%20Basketball">Cincinnati–Louisville rivalry</a> with the first game at <a href="Fifth%20Third%20Arena">Fifth Third Arena</a>. The series was delayed first due to the <a href="Impact%20of%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20on%20sports">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. Chris Mack later confirmed that the series would not be played during the 2021–22 season, putting the resumption of the rivalry into question.
Men's Basketball.
<a href="Cincinnati%20Bearcats%20men%27s%20basketball">Cincinnati</a> and <a href="Louisville%20Cardinals%20men%27s%20basketball">Louisville</a> were rivals, first playing in 1921, until the <a href="2010%E2%80%9314%20NCAA%20conference%20realignment">2010–14 NCAA conference realignment</a> put the contest on hiatus, as Louisville moved to the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> on July 1, 2014. The teams have faced off 99 times in basketball series history, with Louisville leading the all-time series 53–43.
The Bearcats and Cardinals have played in eight conference tournaments, with the Bearcats and Cardinals tied at 4–4. Louisville won all 3 games in the <a href="Metro%20Conference">Metro Conference</a> with Cincinnati winning all 3 games in <a href="Conference%20USA">Conference USA</a>. The teams split 1–1 in the <a href="Big%20East%20%281979%E2%80%932013%29">Big East</a> tournament.
The teams have also met twice in the NCAA Tournament, tied overall at 1–1.
Notable Games.
March 21, 1959: The Bearcats met the Cardinals on their home court, <a href="Freedom%20Hall">Freedom Hall</a>, for the Third Place game of the <a href="1959%20NCAA%20University%20Division%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA Tournament</a>. <a href="Oscar%20Robertson">Oscar Robertson</a> would score 39 points, earning the first <a href="triple%20double">triple double</a> in Final Four history, leading his Bearcats to a 98–85 victory.
January 21, 1967: The No. 2 Cardinals led by eventual All-American <a href="Wes%20Unseld">Wes Unseld</a> visited the <a href="Armory%20Fieldhouse">Armory Fieldhouse</a> to take on the Bearcats. Despite the difference in talent, the entire game was close. With two seconds remaining, Bearcat Gordie Smith threw in a fifteen foot jumper to win the game 59–58 for UC.
March 20, 1975: The No. 3 Cardinals collided with the No. 12 Bearcats in the Sweet Sixteen of the <a href="1975%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA Tournament</a>. Louisville took a solid lead in the first half which proved too much for the Bearcats to overcome, seeing the Cardinals win 78–63. Louisville would go on to finish 3rd overall in the tournament.
January 7, 1978: The Bearcats entered the matchup, tied for the longest home winning streak in the nation at 60 games. The first matchup at <a href="Riverfront%20Coliseum">Riverfront Coliseum</a>, No. 10 Louisville would snap the Cincinnati streak, winning 78–75.
March 8, 1981: The reigning National Champion Cardinals took on the Bearcats in the final of the <a href="Metro%20Conference%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">Metro Conference Tournament</a> at Freedom Hall. In an ugly, low-scoring affair, the Cardinals were triumphant in the game to a score of 42–31.
January 20, 1986: The Bearcats headed to <a href="Freedom%20Hall">Freedom Hall</a> to take on the No. 18, and eventual national champion, Cardinals. With Louisville pulling ahead their lead, Bearcat Roger McClendon would score 24 of his 35 points in the second half to gain an 84–82 victory for Cincinnati.
March 8, 1996: In 1991 Cincinnati left the Metro Conference to form the <a href="Great%20Midwest%20Conference">Great Midwest Conference</a>, putting the rivalry on a five-year hiatus. In 1995, the Great Midwest and Metro combined to form <a href="Conference%20USA">Conference USA</a> bringing the Bearcats and Cardinals back into the same conference. No. 21 Louisville took the first game 72–66 at the <a href="Fifth%20Third%20Arena">Shoemaker Center</a> in February, but with revenge on their mind the <a href="Bob%20Huggins">Bob Huggins</a> lead No. 8 Bearcats defeated No. 22 Louisville in the <a href="1996%20Conference%20USA%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">Conference Tournament</a> Quarterfinals 92–81. In the <a href="1996%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA Tournament</a> the Bearcats advanced to the Elite Eight and the Cardinals made it to the Sweet Sixteen.
February 22, 2003: No. 4 Louisville traveled to Cincinnati and were stunned by the 31 point performance of Leonard Stokes that would help navigate the Bearcats to the 101–80 upset of the Cardinals. The Bearcats would also set a school record, shooting 42-of-58 on free throws in the game.
March 11, 2004: Cincinnati and Louisville faced off in the <a href="2004%20Conference%20USA%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">2004 Conference USA Men's Basketball Tournament</a> hosted at <a href="Heritage%20Bank%20Center">US Bank Arena</a> in Cincinnati. After splitting the regular season matchups, the Bearcats proved too much for <a href="Rick%20Pitino">Rick Pitino</a>'s Cardinals winning 64–62 after Armein Kirkland banked a shot in for the Bearcats with only 16.9 seconds remaining. The No. 13 Bearcats would go on to win the conference tournament. This game was Huggins's last victory in the matchup.
March 10, 2012†: In an unlikely <a href="2012%20Big%20East%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">Big East Tournament</a> championship game, Louisville and Cincinnati faced off, with <a href="Mick%20Cronin%20%28basketball%29">Mick Cronin</a> coaching against his former boss Pitino. Cincinnati fought their way past No. 13 <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Georgetown%20Hoyas%20men%27s%20basketball%20team">Georgetown</a> in double overtime and No. 2 <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Syracuse%20Orange%20men%27s%20basketball%20team">Syracuse</a> while Louisville beat No. 9 <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Marquette%20Golden%20Eagles%20men%27s%20basketball%20team">Marquette</a> and No. 23 <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Notre%20Dame%20Fighting%20Irish%20men%27s%20basketball%20team">Notre Dame</a>. Louisville ended up winning the tilt 50–44, in what was the lowest scoring championship game in Big East history. Both teams made runs in the <a href="2012%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA Tournament</a> with Cincinnati advancing to the Sweet Sixteen and Louisville making it to the Final Four.
February 22, 2014†: In the last matchup between rivals before Louisville left for the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> the teams met at <a href="Fifth%20Third%20Arena">Fifth Third Arena</a>. No. 7 Cincinnati and No. 11 Louisville played in a memorable, blow-for-blow game which would see <a href="Sean%20Kilpatrick">Sean Kilpatrick</a> record 28 points. However, in the dwindling seconds of the second half, <a href="Russ%20Smith%20%28basketball%29">Russ Smith</a> scored with 3 seconds remaining, earning Louisville a 58–57 victory.

Women's Basketball.
Louisville leads the all time contest in Women's basketball 41–27. Similar to men's basketball and football, the teams have not played since Louisville departed for the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> after the 2013–14 season.
Baseball.
One of the series that has continued since conference realignment has been games between the baseball teams. The teams have continued to play yearly, with the two having faced off 182 times in their history after first playing in 1924. Louisville leads the series all time, 100–82 as of the 2021 season.
In 2013, Cincinnati and Louisville played the first ever <a href="college%20baseball">college baseball</a> game at <a href="Great%20American%20Ballpark">Great American Ballpark</a>, the home of the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> on April 6, 2013. The No. 9 Cardinals would defeat the Bearcats 4–1.
On March 21, 2017, the No. 1 Louisville Cardinals played the Cincinnati Bearcats at <a href="UC%20Baseball%20Stadium">UC Baseball Stadium</a>. Cincinnati pulled off an upset, beating Louisville 6–3 and handing the Cardinals their first loss of the season.
On March 30, 2021, the No. 5 Louisville Cardinals were again upset by the Bearcats, 13-12 in a walk-off 10th inning win for Cincinnati.
